thread.title: Hockey says budget has helped jobs grow
thread.title_full: Hockey says budget has helped jobs grow

title: Hockey says budget has helped jobs grow
text:
Tue, Aug 11, 2015, 7:22 PM AEST - Australia Markets closed Hockey says budget has helped jobs grow AAP â€“ 46 minutes ago View Photo 

Treasurer Joe Hockey believes his "important and strategic" May budget has helped boost employment growth, as seen in the latest labour force figures. 
"The only friend of the working Australian is a coalition government," Mr Hockey boasted during the first parliamentary question time following the long winter recess. 
Last week's jobs figures for July proved a mixed bag, with the number of people employed increasing by a healthy 38,500 but the jobless rate unexpectedly rising to 6.3 per cent. 
Prime Minister Tony Abbott conceded on Tuesday that while unemployment is higher than he would like, more than 330,000 jobs have been created since the 2013 election. 
Opposition employment spokesman Brendan O'Connor pointed out to the prime minister that there are more than 800,000 people out of work for the first time in more than 20 years, a 114,000 increase since the coalition came to power. 
"And ... there are 330,000 more employed Australians," Mr Abbott reiterated in reply. 
Mr Hockey said there has been a monthly jobs increase of 23,000 on average since the beginning of 2015, compared with just 3600 when Labor left office. 
However, new figures suggest future employment growth may not be so robust. 
The influential National Australia Bank business survey shows a renewed decline in its employment index for July, suggesting jobs growth of more like 15,000 a month. 
More broadly, the survey was disappointing, with conditions easing and confidence recoiling from its highest level in nearly two years. 
The mining sector was worst hit after recent concerns over economic growth in China - Australia's number one trading partner. 
But despite the fall in conditions, NAB chief economist Alan Oster said trading and profitability remain "relatively elevated". 
ANZ economists blamed "political dramas" for the fall in business confidence, with some opinion polls showing a sharp fall in the government's approval ratings. 
The ANZ-Roy Morgan weekly gauge of consumer confidence eased a modest 0.4 per cent, partially eating into the 5.5 per cent rise in the past three weeks. 
ANZ chief economist Warren Hogan said the bounce in June retail sales reported last week was encouraging, but he expected that the boost from the May budget will be temporary and the housing market will be less stimulative next year. 
"This means that it will be essential for other drivers of confidence and spending - namely jobs and wages - to lift as housing tails off," Mr Hogan said. @y7finance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook
